result.execSummary:
The defendant was charged with both Operating with Prohibited Alcohol Concentration - 4th Offense in 5 Years, Alcohol Fine Enhancer [Modifiers: Alcohol Fine Enhancer, Penalty - Operating While Under the Influence (4th w/in 5 yrs)] and Operating a Motor Vehicle While Intoxicated - 4th Offense in 5 Years, Alcohol Fine Enhancer [Modifiers: Alcohol Fine Enhancer, Penalty - Operating While Under the Influence (4th w/in 5 yrs)]. The defendant was found guilty of Operating with Prohibited Alcohol Concentration - 4th Offense in 5 Years, Alcohol Fine Enhancer [Modifiers: Alcohol Fine Enhancer, Penalty - Operating While Under the Influence (4th w/in 5 yrs)] and the other charge, Operating a Motor Vehicle While Intoxicated - 4th Offense in 5 Years, Alcohol Fine Enhancer [Modifiers: Alcohol Fine Enhancer, Penalty - Operating While Under the Influence (4th w/in 5 yrs)] was dismissed by the court.

  • Brooks Kenneth Hoffmann was found guilty of Operating with Prohibited Alcohol Concentration - 4th Offense in 5 Years, Alcohol Fine Enhancer [Modifiers: Alcohol Fine Enhancer, Penalty - Operating While Under the Influence (4th w/in 5 yrs)], a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(b).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

charges.descr: Operating a Motor Vehicle While Intoxicated - 4th Offense in 5 Years, Alcohol Fine Enhancer

chargeModifiers.descr: Penalty - Operating While Under the Influence (4th w/in 5 yrs)

supervisions.notes: In the event that the defendant is discharged from probation with outstanding financial obligations, the supervising agent SHALL notify the court 10 days prior to the revocation or discharge.  A civil judgment SHALL be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.  04/06/16: Court orders probation will terminate on 04/20/2016.

Any vehicle(s) titled in the Defendant's name and/or any vehicle(s) operated by the Defendant are subject to an ignition interlock device.  The ignition interlock requirement becomes effective when the Defendant applies for a license.
Defendant is to receive an alcohol assessment and comply with any driver's safety plan.

miscConds.notes: Defendant is to pay the Blood Draw Fee and the Ignition Interlock Surcharge.

Defendant is to comply with any treatment/programming as deemed appropriate by the COMPAS assessment and agent.  Defendant is to follow the requirements of Recovery Court.  Defendant is to report for Recovery Court on 2/25/15 at 9:00 am.

timeConds.notes: The second 6 months of the Defendant's jail sentence is stayed, as long as the Defendant is following through with Recovery Court requirements.  Defendant is eligible for huber privileges after the 1st 48 hours.  Defendant is eligible for Electronic Monitoring after the 1st 48 hours.  Defendant's jail credit is to be applied toward the 1st 48 hours of confinement.
